[b]Section 1: Leadership[/b]

[b]Leadership Training[/b]
Take a job or volunteer in a position where you will be leading or managing people, any experience will begin to hone your skills, even if it is only shift lead at the burger hut.

[b]Confidence[/b]
Build your confidence by leading in sports, competitions, and problem solving exercises. Volunteering gives many opportunities to become comfortable in leadership.

[b]Honesty[/b]
A leader at any level must be beyond reproach. If every member acted as if there was a news camera crew following them there would be less of a chance for disappointment or even blackmail.

[b]Punctuality[/b]
Keep appointments and show up on time, or better yet, early. People appreciate having their time treated as if it is valuable, and will respect you for it.

[b]Join In[/b]
Join in and help with the work in a motivated way. Those following you will see your real commitment and be motivated themselves.

[b]Delegate Authority[/b]
Designate competent leaders and allow them to build a team and take care of the task. Your oversight should balance your stake in the outcome with your trust in delegate leaders.
